newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia dlr drops 1/2 cent after budget.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia dlr drops 1/2 cent after budget.

text.p: The Australian dollar slid 1/2 U.S. cent in brisk trade after the 1997/98 Federal budget proved to be looser than the market had been hoping for.

By 8.00 p.m. (1000 GMT) the dollar had lost all the day's gains, falling to US$0.7775/80 from US$0.7826/31 just before the budget details hit dealing screens 30 minutes earlier, to be back at Tuesday's local finish.
Dealers said US$0.7775 was a support level, with the next level being US$0.7750.

The government projected an underlying shortfall of A$3.9 billion for the next financial year, around A$2.0 billion more than analysts had looked for. The headline surplus was also far smaller than recent speculation had favoured.
The dollar had edged higher through the day, partly in anticipation of a tight budget which would cut up to A$2.0 billion in government spending.
The actual cuts were a mere A$352 million, which analysts saw as a worrying sign of a slackening in resolve by the government in adressing Australia's long term savings problems.

The economic forecasts underpinning the budget were deemed mixed by analysts. A GDP growth rate of 3.75 percent pencilled in for 1997/98 melded well with median market expectations of 3.9 percent, but the government saw underlying inflation at 2.0 percent when analysts reckoned 2.5 percent was more likely.
